Award.AwardTitle: Role of Sec7 Domain Guanine Nucleotide Exchange Factors in Membrane Traffic

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Membrane traffic mediates secretion and the delivery of proteins and lipids to intracellular organelles and the plasma membrane. The mechanisms regulating this process are largely conserved throughout all eukaryotes and what is learned in one species can reveal events occurring in other species (including humans). In unicellular organisms, membrane traffic sustains cell growth and interactions with the environment. In multicellular organisms, membrane traffic is required for deposition of the extracellular matrix and cell adhesion, the release and uptake of growth factors and nutrients, and the insertion of environment sensing receptor and signal transducers, i.e., all the processes that integrate the developmental and physiological responses of tissues and organs. This project will focus on key regulators of membrane traffic, the ADP-ribosylation factor (ARF) GTPases. Specifically, the mechanisms and molecules that facilitate ARF activation will be identified and characterized. This project studies the molecular mechanisms that regulate membrane trafficking to understand a process essential for cellular and organismal life.

Broader Impacts
The broader impacts of this project are: (1) Training and mentoring of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students and undergraduates in cutting-edge molecular, imaging, biochemical and genetic technologies to probe key questions in cellular physiology. (2) Promoting scientific equity by actively recruiting and mentoring under-represented groups to enter scientific careers. (3) Promoting interdisciplinary synergy by interfacing with structural and biophysical scientists to provide additional cross-field fertilization of technologies and ideas. (4) Promoting global scientific infrastructure by developing and disseminating plasmids, antibodies, recombinant proteins and experimental approaches to labs worldwide. This project has additional societal benefits because it will provide the next generation of academic researchers and teachers, improve the competitiveness of US scientific enterprise and prepare highly trained individuals for non-academic jobs in science and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Findings from our studies provide fundamental new knowledge of how cells regulate secretion, an essential process in all eukaryotic cells. Secretion requires the production of transport vesicles that selectively package and transport cargo proteins through the secretory pathway. We study the molecular events that regulate the formation of transport vesicles. Our studies probe the very early steps of vesicle formation and aim to understand how the cell “knows” when and where to make vesicles. We focused on a molecule called GBF1 that initiates vesicle formation and therefore acts as the cellular “decider” of where and when a vesicle will form. To understand how GBF1 functions, we generated numerous mutants of GBF1 and assessed their ability to support vesicle formation. Through these analyses, we identified key regions of GBF1 that mediate distinct functions of this molecule. In addition, we defined how GBF1 itself can be regulated in cells to be either active or inactive in vesicle formation. Together, our findings are important because they identify the regulatory nexus that impacts vesicle formation and hence regulates the secretory traffic essential for all cellular life. Such foundational knowledge is essential for future approaches to manipulate the secretory pathway.

An equally important outcome of our work is that it lays the foundation for a system-level understanding of secretion. Our molecular studies form the foundation for a future project to model through mathematical and computational approaches the spatio-temporal regulation of vesicle formation. Such analysis is essential to gain insight into the emergent properties of the process that can’t be gained from experimental data alone. Thus, findings from this award provide the stepping-stone for the “next level” analysis of vesicular traffic. Therefore, in addition to impacting the field of Cell Biology, our findings will impact the field of Mathematics and Computational analyses, and will propel the development of novel mathematical and computational programs and approaches.

The funding of this project supported numerous teaching and training activities of individuals at multiple levels of professional development. It facilitated the training of undergraduate students to expose them to bench science and share the excitement and rewards of doing cutting-edge research. As a result of such exposure, many of these students will select careers in scientific or health professions. It also supported training of doctoral graduate students to prepare them for a career in biological research. In addition, it supported scientific and professional mentoring of post-doctoral trainees to enable them to compete for independent professional positions. All trainees were exposed to a variety of scientific approaches and technologies that utilized molecular, imaging, biochemical and genetic methods to illuminate basic cell biological processes. All were mentored in the ethical conduct of science and received individualized instruction and mentoring to develop and optimize their careers. Many of the trainees were women and members of under-represented minority groups. They represent the next generation of the US scientific work force and will undoubtedly play seminal roles in the future of the US scientific enterprise.
